html.p: Why: Makes it look like you know what you are doing.
So What: Makes 'bad' field names easier to work with, or converts shorthand names to longer ones at the end of your SPL.
Be careful! You'd think rename wouldn't cause problems, but you can overwrite fields with null and cause other minor mayhem.
We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup
While yours may differ slightly, that data for us is:

panel.title: Our original data
panel.html: You know, that field cars isn't real descriptive.

panel.title: Renaming a field
panel.html: So we | rename cars AS "Cars Sold This Hour"

search.query: | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv | rename cars AS "Cars Sold This Hour"

panel.title: Another example
panel.html: You can make all the fields pretty. Just do yourself a favor, only rename things to have spaces in them at the end of your search. It's painful if you do that too soon.

html.p:
Also you can rename multiple fields at once, like | rename salesperson AS "Sales Person" cars AS "Cars Sold" _time as Time.
NOTE _time is even more special than the other _* fields. It is stored as unix epoch time, then at display time converted to your default time format. When you rename it, that specialness gets lost. You can "fix" it with eval though.

search.query: | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv | rename salesperson AS "Sales Person" cars AS "Cars Sold" _time as Time
